text: On Monday I had lunch with Alan Kay! I wrote a long thing trying to make sense of it. I wrote it as a rough notes thing, so I'm mostly looking for reactions instead of feedback, per se: <https://futureofcoding.org/notes/alan-kay-lunch>

text: Five hour lunches are the best lunches.  Support the learning enjoyment tax.  Resource curse of too much low hanging low fiber fruit.  Read <http://dougengelbart.org/content/view/138/000/> then read it again.  No, Newton wasn’t a Newtonian.  40h/1m video is not bad at all.

text: "Use the same langauge for printers as for screens", he may refer to this <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NeWS> and <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Display_PostScript>

attachments.title: NeWS
attachments.text: NeWS (Network extensible Window System) is a discontinued windowing system developed by Sun Microsystems in the mid-1980s. Originally known as "SunDew", its primary authors were James Gosling and David S. H. Rosenthal. The NeWS interpreter was based on PostScript (as was the later Display PostScript, although the two projects were otherwise unrelated) extending it to allow interaction and multiple "contexts" to support windows. Like PostScript, NeWS could be used as a complete programming language, but unlike PostScript, NeWS could be used to make complete interactive programs with mouse support and a GUI.

attachments.title: Display PostScript
attachments.text:
Display PostScript (or DPS) is a 2D graphics engine system for computers which uses the PostScript (PS) imaging model and language (originally developed for computer printing) to generate on-screen graphics. To the basic PS system, DPS adds a number of features intended to ease working with bitmapped displays and improve performance of some common tasks.
Early versions of PostScript display systems were developed at Adobe Systems. During development of the NeXT computers, NeXT and Adobe collaborated to produce the official DPS system, which was released in 1987. NeXT used DPS throughout its history, while versions from Adobe were popular on Unix workstations for a time during the 1980s and 1990s.

text:
The quality of the write-up is excellent.

I'm skeptical of "Reading a couple hundred books a year is the bare minimum. It’s just the baseline." It's the baseline to get to where Alan Kay is now, for better and for worse. But I suspect you need more than Alan Kay to get where you're going. Too much book learning could be where he went astray. At a couple hundred books per year you'd finish his recommendations in a year and still have time to do things in later years. Or you could read 20 books per year for ten years and actually play with some of the ideas you're reading about.

I don't mean to say that Alan Kay is just reading books without doing anything, year in and year out. Just using contrast for rhetorical purpose. I don't actually know what missteps projects like Dynabook or STEPS may have made. But it's worth keeping those possibilities on your radar to avoid survivor bias in your thinking.

text: Reflecting on these notes, I wrote about Art, Music, Science, and Theatre, with tie-ins to Programming and a life of immersion: <http://ivanish.ca/lunch-with-alan-kay/>

text: At the risk of going against the flow, I want to put forth the suggestion that maybe Alan Kay isn't quite the messiah he's sometimes worked up to be. He's an intelligent man for sure, but to some degree eccentric, and it's unclear whether his advice is actually good advice. He did contribute to some major advances in the 20th century, but his achievements in recent decades are more minor, so it doesn't appear his formula is working out even for himself anymore.

text: One requirement of being a leader (including a thought leader) is being a good speaker and salesman. Alan Kay definitely fits that bill, but you have to peel back the presentation layer and look beneath to see if the underlying content is any good. Donald Trump is also a good salesman, but because we (tech people) are not his target audience, most of us here have likely concluded that the content he's selling is of questionable quality. With salesman who are targeting us (tech people) directly, I think it's harder to see the reality of the content. Personally, after casually buying Alan Kay's content for a few years, I've since become skeptical of it.

text: <@UCGAK10LS>, I want to agree that Alan Kay, like anyone else, deserves both respect and critique.  For example, it's quite fair to consider whether STEPS was a good idea for a project.  What came up it?  What went right?  What went wrong?  Whether it was successful?  By what measure?  And what can we learn from it?
